Authors: Lu, Weili; Bates, Francine; Waynor, William; Bazan, Carolyn; Yanos, Philip T.; Gao, Carol; Librera, LueAnn; Giacobbe, Giovanna; Schultz, Emily; Rogers, Krista
Article Title: Work is the best medicine: A qualitative analysis of posttraumatic stress disorder and supported employment
Abstract: Co-occurring posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) negatively impacts employment outcomes for individuals with serious mental health conditions (SMHCs). This study examined how employment might help individuals manage PTSD. Sixty-eight employed individuals with SMHCs and co-occurring PTSD responded to two open-ended questions focused on how work impacted the management of PTSD symptoms and their perceived need for support from a job coach. Findings revealed themes about benefits of work on PTSD symptom management and types of provider support desired. Study implications are discussed.

llama-3.2-3b-instruct.reason: The study design lacks a control group.

qwen2.5-7b-instruct-1m.reason: The study design is qualitative (qualitative analysis) and lacks a rigorous evaluation or control group. It does not meet the inclusion criteria for study design.

phi-3-mini-4k-instruct.reason: The study does not focus on employment interventions but rather on the impact of employment on PTSD management in individuals with SMHCs.

mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501.reason: The study design is qualitative analysis, which does not meet the inclusion criteria for rigorous evaluation methods such as meta-analyses, systematic reviews of controlled trials, RCTs, or quasi-experimental studies with a control group.
